1.1.1.description: Network security controls are implemented and managed according to documented policies and procedures.

1.1.2.description: Roles and responsibilities for managing network security are documented, assigned, and understood.

1.2.1.description: Network security controls are configured to deny all traffic by default, only allowing necessary communication.

1.2.2.description: Network security controls are reviewed and tested at least annually to ensure effectiveness.

1.3.1.description: Inbound and outbound network traffic is restricted to only what is necessary for business purposes.

1.3.2.description: Firewall rules are documented and reviewed regularly.

1.4.1.description: Connections to untrusted networks are approved and securely configured.

1.4.2.description: Remote access is controlled and secured with strong authentication.

1.5.1.description: The organization has formally assigned roles and responsibilities for managing network security.

1.5.2.description: Documentation exists that outlines the specific duties of personnel responsible for network security.

1.5.3.description: Personnel responsible for managing network security have been trained and have the necessary expertise.

1.5.4.description: The organization regularly reviews and updates network security responsibilities to align with changes in technology and threats.

1.5.5.description: Network security responsibilities are communicated to relevant stakeholders, including IT staff, management, and third-party providers.

2.1.1.description: Security configuration standards are documented and maintained.

2.1.2.description: Secure configuration policies align with industry best practices.

2.2.1.description: Default passwords and settings are changed before deployment.

2.2.2.description: Unnecessary services, functions, and accounts are disabled.

2.2.3.description: Security parameters for system components are configured securely.

2.3.1.description: Security settings for system components are reviewed regularly.

2.3.2.description: Secure protocols and encryption methods are implemented.

2.4.1.description: Configuration standards align with industry best practices.

2.4.2.description: Compliance with configuration standards is reviewed regularly.

2.5.1.description: System security settings are hardened based on risk assessments.

2.6.1.description: Configuration changes follow a formal change management process.

3.1.1.description: A formal data protection policy is documented, reviewed, and maintained.

3.1.2.description: Responsibilities for protecting stored cardholder data are assigned and understood.

3.2.1.description: Cardholder data retention is minimized based on business and legal requirements.

3.2.2.description: Cardholder data storage locations are documented and reviewed regularly.

3.2.3.description: Stored data is deleted when no longer needed for business or legal purposes.

3.3.1.description: Full magnetic stripe data, CVV, PINs, or other sensitive authentication data are never stored post-authorization.

3.3.2.description: Systems are configured to prevent the storage of sensitive authentication data.

3.4.1.description: PAN is encrypted, tokenized, or masked when stored.

3.4.2.description: PAN truncation follows industry best practices.

3.5.1.description: Cryptographic keys are securely stored and protected from unauthorized access.

3.5.2.description: Key management policies ensure that encryption keys are rotated periodically.

3.6.1.description: Strong encryption algorithms are used for data protection.

3.6.2.description: Cryptographic implementations follow industry-accepted best practices.

4.1.1.description: A formal policy for encrypting cardholder data in transit is documented and maintained.

4.1.2.description: Responsibilities for managing encryption and data transmission security are assigned and understood.

4.2.1.description: Only trusted cryptographic protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2 or higher) are used to encrypt cardholder data during transmission.

4.2.2.description: Weak encryption protocols (e.g., SSL/TLS versions lower than 1.2) are disabled.

4.3.1.description: Cardholder data is never transmitted in cleartext over open networks.

4.3.2.description: Wireless transmissions of cardholder data are encrypted using industry-accepted protocols.

4.3.3.description: Secure email, instant messaging, or file transfer protocols are used when transmitting sensitive data.

4.4.1.description: Encryption keys are stored securely using industry best practices (e.g., hardware security modules).

4.4.2.description: Encryption keys used for data transmission are rotated periodically and updated as per cryptographic policies.

5.1.1.description: A formal anti-malware policy is documented and maintained.

5.1.2.description: Responsibilities for malware protection are assigned and understood.

5.2.1.description: Systems commonly affected by malware have active anti-malware protection installed.

5.2.2.description: Anti-malware solutions perform regular scans and real-time monitoring of system activity.

5.2.3.description: Anti-malware solutions are configured to prevent, detect, and respond to known threats.

5.3.1.description: Anti-malware signatures and software are updated automatically or manually at least daily.

5.3.2.description: Anti-malware solutions are reviewed periodically to ensure effectiveness.

5.4.1.description: Malware infections are logged and monitored.

5.4.2.description: Systems are configured to alert administrators when malware is detected.

5.4.3.description: Malware incidents are investigated and remediated in a timely manner.

5.5.1.description: Only authorized software is installed and executed on systems handling cardholder data.

5.5.2.description: Mechanisms such as allow-listing or application control are used to prevent unauthorized software execution.

6.1.1.description: Security policies and procedures for software development and system maintenance are documented and updated regularly.

6.1.2.description: Responsibilities for maintaining secure systems and software are assigned and understood.

6.2.1.description: A process is in place to identify, evaluate, and prioritize security vulnerabilities.

6.2.2.description: Security patches are applied to system components based on risk assessments and vendor recommendations.

6.2.3.description: Critical security patches are applied within the time frame defined by organizational policy.

6.3.1.description: Secure coding guidelines are documented and integrated into the software development lifecycle (SDLC).

6.3.2.description: Developers receive training on secure coding practices.

6.3.3.description: Software security requirements are documented before development begins.

6.3.4.description: Security testing is conducted at each phase of development.

6.4.1.description: Web applications are protected against common vulnerabilities such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting (XSS).

6.4.2.description: Applications are regularly reviewed and tested for security weaknesses.

6.5.1.description: Protections such as web application firewalls (WAFs) and runtime application self-protection (RASP) are implemented where applicable.

6.5.2.description: Controls are in place to block known attack techniques against system components.

6.6.1.description: Security patches are tested before deployment to ensure compatibility.

6.6.2.description: Patch deployment is documented, monitored, and verified.

7.1.1.description: Access control policies and procedures are documented, reviewed, and updated regularly.

7.1.2.description: Access control mechanisms are implemented based on business needs and the principle of least privilege.

7.2.1.description: Only authorized users have access to system components and cardholder data.

7.2.2.description: Role-based access controls (RBAC) are implemented to restrict access based on job responsibilities.

7.2.3.description: System access is granted based on the principle of least privilege.

7.3.1.description: User access permissions are reviewed at least every six months.

7.3.2.description: Accounts that are no longer required (e.g., terminated employees) are removed or disabled immediately.

7.3.3.description: Changes to user access permissions follow a documented approval process.

7.4.1.description: System administrators and privileged accounts have the minimum necessary access to perform their job duties.

7.4.2.description: Emergency or temporary access is granted only when necessary and is revoked after use.

7.4.3.description: Privileged access is monitored and logged for security auditing.

8.1.1.description: Authentication policies and procedures are documented, reviewed, and updated regularly.

8.1.2.description: Authentication requirements cover all system components that handle cardholder data.

8.2.1.description: Each individual user is assigned a unique ID before being granted system access.

8.2.2.description: Group or shared accounts are not used for accessing cardholder data.

8.2.3.description: User accounts are reviewed periodically to ensure proper authorization.

8.3.1.description: Passwords, biometrics, or other authentication methods meet industry security standards.

8.3.2.description: Default and vendor-supplied authentication credentials are changed before deployment.

8.3.3.description: Authentication credentials are protected from unauthorized disclosure and reuse.

8.4.1.description: MFA is required for all non-console administrative access to system components.

8.4.2.description: MFA is required for remote access to the cardholder data environment (CDE).

8.4.3.description: MFA implementations are tested and reviewed for effectiveness.

8.5.1.description: Minimum password length and complexity requirements are defined and enforced.

8.5.2.description: Authentication credentials must be changed periodically, based on risk assessment.

8.5.3.description: Account lockout policies are enforced after a defined number of failed login attempts.

8.6.1.description: Passwords are stored using strong cryptographic methods.

8.6.2.description: Authentication credentials are transmitted securely using encryption.

8.6.3.description: User authentication logs are monitored and reviewed for suspicious activity.

9.1.1.description: Policies and procedures for physical security are documented and reviewed.

9.1.2.description: Physical security policies cover all areas where cardholder data is stored or processed.

9.2.1.description: Access to physical locations containing cardholder data is restricted to authorized personnel only.

9.2.2.description: Visitors are required to sign in, wear identification, and be escorted at all times in secure areas.

9.2.3.description: Visitor logs are maintained and reviewed regularly.

9.3.1.description: Visitors are granted access only for specific, authorized purposes.

9.3.2.description: Visitor logs include name, organization, date/time of entry and exit, and purpose of visit.

9.3.3.description: Visitor logs are retained for at least three months.

9.4.1.description: Workstations and servers that process cardholder data are physically secured.

9.4.2.description: Access to sensitive areas, including data centers and server rooms, is monitored and logged.

9.4.3.description: Access to removable media containing cardholder data is controlled.

9.5.1.description: All media containing cardholder data (e.g., hard drives, backup tapes, USB drives) is labeled and securely stored.

9.5.2.description: Media storage locations are secured with access restrictions.

9.5.3.description: Movement of media is logged and tracked.

9.6.1.description: Media containing cardholder data is rendered unreadable before disposal (e.g., shredding, degaussing, or secure wipe).

9.6.2.description: Secure disposal policies are documented and followed by all personnel handling sensitive media.

9.6.3.description: Third-party disposal services are reviewed and monitored to ensure compliance with secure disposal policies.

10.1.1.description: Logging policies and procedures are documented, reviewed, and updated regularly.

10.1.2.description: Logging mechanisms are implemented to track system activity.

10.2.1.description: Logs capture user activities, including access to sensitive systems and data.

10.2.2.description: Logs include details such as user ID, event type, date/time, and system component affected.

10.2.3.description: All administrative access, root/superuser activity, and changes to security configurations are logged.

10.2.4.description: Failed login attempts and account lockouts are recorded.

10.3.1.description: Log files are stored securely and access is restricted to authorized personnel.

10.3.2.description: Log integrity mechanisms prevent tampering and unauthorized modifications.

10.3.3.description: Log retention policies ensure logs are retained for at least one year, with three months of logs immediately available for analysis.

10.4.1.description: Logs are reviewed daily to identify suspicious activity.

10.4.2.description: Automated log monitoring tools are used to detect anomalies.

10.4.3.description: Alerts for unusual access patterns or security events are investigated promptly.

10.5.1.description: A Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) solution or equivalent is deployed to correlate and analyze logs in real-time.

10.5.2.description: Critical security alerts are escalated and addressed immediately.

10.6.1.description: Incident response procedures are in place for handling log anomalies.

10.6.2.description: Security incidents detected through log analysis are escalated and remediated.

10.6.3.description: Incident reports are documented, and lessons learned are applied to improve security monitoring.

11.1.1.description: A formal security testing process is established.

11.1.2.description: Security testing procedures align with industry best practices.

11.2.1.description: Internal vulnerability scans are conducted at least quarterly and after significant changes.

11.2.2.description: External vulnerability scans are performed at least quarterly by an Approved Scanning Vendor (ASV).

11.2.3.description: Identified vulnerabilities are remediated according to risk rankings.

11.3.1.description: Internal and external penetration testing is performed at least annually.

11.3.2.description: Penetration tests cover application-layer and network-layer vulnerabilities.

11.3.3.description: Penetration testing includes exploitation of identified vulnerabilities.

11.3.4.description: Segmentation testing is performed at least annually to ensure isolation of the cardholder data environment (CDE).

11.4.1.description: Intrusion detection or prevention systems (IDS/IPS) monitor critical network traffic.

11.4.2.description: IDS/IPS alerts are monitored and responded to in a timely manner.

11.4.3.description: IDS/IPS configurations are reviewed and updated regularly.

11.5.1.description: File integrity monitoring (FIM) solutions are deployed to detect unauthorized changes.

11.5.2.description: Critical system files and configurations are monitored for unexpected modifications.

11.5.3.description: Alerts for unauthorized changes are investigated and resolved.

11.6.1.description: Mechanisms are implemented to detect unauthorized modifications to payment pages.

11.6.2.description: Unauthorized modifications are logged, investigated, and remediated.

11.6.3.description: The integrity of e-commerce payment pages is reviewed periodically.

12.1.1.description: Information security policies are documented, reviewed, and updated regularly.

12.1.2.description: Policies cover all applicable PCI DSS requirements.

12.2.1.description: Acceptable use policies define security responsibilities for employees and third parties.

12.2.2.description: Policies are communicated to all relevant personnel.

12.3.1.description: A formal risk assessment process is in place.

12.3.2.description: Security risks are identified, evaluated, and mitigated.

12.3.3.description: Risk assessments are conducted at least annually.

12.4.1.description: Senior management is responsible for implementing and maintaining security policies.

12.4.2.description: Security roles and responsibilities are clearly defined.

12.5.1.description: A formal security awareness program is implemented.

12.5.3.description: Security training includes social engineering and phishing awareness.

12.6.1.description: An incident response plan is documented and maintained.

12.6.2.description: Incident response procedures include roles, responsibilities, and escalation paths.

12.6.3.description: The incident response plan is tested at least annually.

12.6.4.description: Employees are trained on incident response procedures.

12.7.1.description: Contracts with third-party providers include PCI DSS compliance requirements.

12.7.2.description: Third-party security responsibilities are reviewed and monitored.

12.8.1.description: An internal compliance monitoring program is implemented.

12.8.2.description: Regular PCI DSS assessments are conducted.

12.8.3.description: Evidence of compliance is maintained and available for audits.
